thread.title: Pope's Philly speech tickets available online at noon Tuesday
thread.title_full: Pope's Philly speech tickets available online at noon Tuesday

author: Scott Kraus
title: Pope's Philly speech tickets available online at noon Tuesday
text:
0 
Tickets, albeit free, will be required to access an area of the Parkway stretching from the steps of the Philadelphia Museum of Art to Logan Circle, about half a mile away. A second zone, shown in purple and stretching from Logan Circle to City Hall, will not require tickets. 
Both zones will be fenced off and participants will need to go through security checkpoints to enter. 
Tickets for the red zone will be distributed primarily to parishes in the Archdiocese of Philadelphia, but also in smaller numbers to parishes in surrounding areas. The Allentown Archdiocese is slated to receive 200 tickets for each event. 
On Thursday, after public outcry about the newly-revealed ticket policy, World Meeting of Families Executive Director Donna Crilley Farrell said festival organizers had decided to release an additional 25,000 tickets to the general public, making them available online over the next week or two. 
The additional tickets included 5,000 passes to Francis' Saturday address on immigration, double the number that had initially been announced. 
Organizers will make 10,000 additional tickets available to the general public for each of the Parkway events, the Festival of Families on Saturday and the mass on Sunday. 
To demonstrate that even non-ticket holders will get a chance to see the pope, organizers announced Thursday that Francis will parade twice on the Parkway, a shorter route on Sunday and a longer route stretching around City Hall and through the non-ticketed area on Saturday. He will also be visible on 40 Jumbotrons scattered around Center City. 
It has been a rollercoaster week for the city and papal visit organizers, who had only just pivoted from explaining and re-explaining security measures to promoting the joys and opportunities presented by Pope Francis' first tour of the United States since his elevation to pontiff. 
Slow sales of special SEPTA passes for regional rail trains heading into the city over the weekend to see the pope and some remaining Center City hotel vacancies began to cause some to speculate turnout might not be a high as the predictions of 1.5 to 2 million. 
SEPTA printed 300,000 of the special $10 day-passes. "We still have plenty available," said Jerri Williams, a SEPTA spokeswoman. Tens of thousands remain unsold. 
An informal hotel room search quickly turned up rooms available at the Holiday Inn Express Midtown for $469 a night for a Friday through Monday stay, and at the Hotel Monaco, a Kimpton boutique hotel in the historic district, for $399 a night.
